awd_titl_txt: Nanoscale Polarization Control for Single Molecule Detection: Circular and Trochoidal Dichroism
awd_abstract_narration:
An object is chiral when it cannot be superimposed on its mirror image.  Our left and right hands are non-superimposable and are therefore chiral objects. Chirality exists throughout nature. The twist of a DNA helix gives it a specific handedness, determined by the twist direction. Light waves can be made to spiral as they travel through space. This special form of light -- called circularly polarized light -- has a specific handedness depending on whether the twist is clock-wise or counter clock-wise.  Circularly polarized light interacts more favorably with chiral objects when their handedness match. Chiral molecules therefore either absorb more left-handed or right-handed circularly polarized light. The difference is known as circular dichroism, which gives important insights into the handedness and geometry of molecules. However, the circular dichroism signal is usually weak.  With support from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry and Chemical Measurement and Imaging programs in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Stephan Link from Rice University is studying individual proteins placed in the gap between two metal nanoparticles, which concentrate the light and amplify the circular dichroism signal. Working with his students, Professor Link is applying advanced assembly methods to control the protein placement and using sophisticated spectroscopies to study the underlying enhancement mechanism, which is still poorly understood. Their discoveries could have far-reaching applicability to understanding neurodegenerative diseases, such as Alzheimer's and Parkinson's. In addition, the project incorporates concepts from multiple disciplines forming an attractive training platform for post-doctoral researchers, graduate, undergraduate, and high school students. 

To exploit defined nanoscale assembly and electric field manipulation for the detection of single chiral molecules and their structural dynamics, the Link lab is applying DNA origami methods for precise control over nanoscale geometry in combination with unique spectroscopic capabilities developed for determining the circular dichroism signals of single molecular-plasmonic complexes. Electromagnetic simulations and electron microscopy aid in the distinction between optical activity arising from the plasmonic nanostructure itself vs. the chiral molecule of interest. These studies are advancing the mechanistic understanding about plasmon-coupled circular dichroism and allow one to create substrates for sensing molecular structure of a single protein using circular dichroism. The project is also studying trochoidal dichroism using surface confined waves created by total internal reflection.  Trochoidal fields have electric components along the propagation direction of light and only exist at an interface. The Link lab is exploring which nanostructure and molecular geometries are sensitive specifically to trochoidal fields when the handedness of the cartwheeling motion of such fields is switched. Professor Link is also participating in Rice University's Civic Scientist Program, allowing him to educate K-12 students about nanotechnology and inspire them to pursue scientific careers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Nanoparticle-based materials are becoming increasingly popular in multiple areas of current technology. This NSF award, titled Nanoscale Polarization Control for Single Molecule Detection: Circular and Trochoidal Dichroism, was funded to investigate the chiroptical properties of nanoparticle-molecule complexes and top-down engineered coupled nanostructures. The results of this research have revealed the possibility to sense single chiral molecules through the detection at the plasmon resonance of the nanoparticle substrate as long as an electromagnetic hotspot is present. The plasmon resonance, the coherent oscillation of conduction band electrons in metal nanoparticles, acts an antenna to read out the chirality of the molecular analyte. Furthermore, our work showed that surface confined electromagnetic waves interact with matter in a way to produce trochoidal dichroism, a new form of dichroism that adds to our understanding of light-matter interactions at interfaces.

 

Chiral objects are not superimposable with their mirror image, or enantiomer. Chirality is commonly illustrated using hands, and thus the chirality of an object is termed its handedness. Chirality is measured by circular dichroism spectroscopy. A major drawback of circular dichroism spectroscopy is the limited sensitivity because of the much smaller length scales of molecular chiral elements compared to the helical pitch of circularly polarized light. Metallic nanostructures have been proposed to enhance the circular dichroism of chiral molecules, but the ultimate detection limit of a single molecule has so far not been reached. A main goal of this project was therefore to determine how plasmons can be used to amplify the circular dichroism of chiral molecules, through a process termed plasmon coupled circular dichroism, and how competing signals from other chiral sources as well as linear dichroism artefacts can be suppressed to enhance overall sensitivity.

 

To accomplish this goal, we determined the origins of structural chirality and the influence of a supporting substrate. We found that for gold nanorods their assemblies lead to large structural chirality that masks plasmon coupled circular dichroism. Transitioning to coupled nanosphere dimers with strong electromagnetic enhancements in the interparticle gap allowed us to suppress structural chirality and isolate plasmon coupled circular dichroism for a protein analyte. We were able to detect as few as a handful of molecules with the detection limit likely being closer to a single protein.

 

We furthermore established a new form of optical dichroism, termed trochoidal dichroism, which complements its circular and linear counterparts. Trochoidal polarizations are characterized by a cartwheeling, or cycloidal, electric field motion occurring in the direction of light propagation and can be found in laterally confined evanescent waves at interfaces. We characterized trochoidal dichroism for coupled nanostructures such as L-shaped nanorod dimers as well as pinwheels with different handedness, fabricated by top-down electron-beam lithography.

 

This NSF award supported research activities for 5 graduate students and 5 postdoctoral researchers over the 4+ years of the grant duration, and yielded 10 publications. Those involved had the opportunity to learn sophisticated single-particle spectroscopy techniques, electron microscopy, data analysis, and electromagnetic modeling. In addition, many projects were carried out in a collaborative effort, teaching the participants how to interact professionally. This aspect was further enhanced through presentations at local and national conferences, as well as by publishing in peer-reviewed journals.

 

Overall, the results of these studies are significant because they set the stage for single-molecule spectroscopy of chiral molecules. Sensitive detection of circular dichroism from biomolecules has the potential for wide applicability in many industries, particularly in pharmaceuticals and therapeutics. The ability to detect protein conformational changes as a result of external stimuli on the single protein level could have far-reaching applicability to understanding neurodegenerative diseases, such as Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s, related to protein unfolding, potentially solving complex biological interactions.
